text: this glowing creature is a millipede
it's light is a warning to predators it
says I make my own cyanide don't eat me
but millipedes may have started out
glowing for no reason at all
scientists at Virginia Tech and the
University of Arizona recently found one
species that everyone thought didn't
glow but it does
they used molecular biology to compare
it to other millipedes and their levels
of bioluminescence as they evolved what
the data suggested was that long ago
millipedes may have started glowing
faintly as an accident of their
metabolism but they also produce cyanide
and has the level of their cyanide
production increased so did
bioluminescence evolution co-opted an
accident and turned it into a warning
today predators can count on one thing
the brighter the millipede the more
cyanide
